reference_range.notes: Reference range varies by age and lab; this is approximate adult range

interpretation_patterns.interpretation: Low IGF-1 in the setting of insulin resistance suggests hepatic GH resistance rather than true GH deficiency. The liver produces IGF-1 in response to GH, but insulin resistance impairs this hepatic response. The patient may have adequate GH but the liver cannot respond properly.
interpretation_patterns.clinical_implications: Consider addressing insulin resistance before initiating GH therapy. GH may be ineffective if hepatic GH signaling is impaired. Focus on metabolic optimization first.
next_steps: Assess liver function and fatty liver status
GH stimulation testing only if IGF-1 remains low after metabolic optimization

peer_reviewed_citations.citation: Sjogren K, Wallenius K, Liu JL, et al. (2001) Liver-derived IGF-I is the principal source of IGF-I in blood. Annals of Medicine. 33(3):138-143
peer_reviewed_citations.relevance: Establishes liver as primary IGF-1 source

interpretation_patterns.interpretation: Low IGF-1 with normal insulin sensitivity is more suggestive of true GH deficiency or inadequate protein/caloric intake. The liver appears capable of responding to GH (no insulin resistance block), but either GH stimulus is insufficient or nutritional substrates are lacking.
interpretation_patterns.clinical_implications: Evaluate nutritional status and consider GH stimulation testing. GH therapy may be appropriate if deficiency is confirmed.
next_steps: Consider GH stimulation testing (insulin tolerance test, glucagon, GHRH-arginine)
Evaluate pituitary function if other axes appear affected

interpretation_patterns.interpretation: Elevated IGF-1 in a longevity context may indicate accelerated growth signaling associated with faster aging and potentially increased cancer risk. However, very low IGF-1 is also associated with frailty and sarcopenia. The optimal zone depends on clinical context.
interpretation_patterns.clinical_implications: In longevity-focused patients, consider whether IGF-1 optimization to mid-range is appropriate. Balance anabolic needs against longevity concerns.
next_steps: Assess patient's goals (anabolism vs longevity optimization)
Consider dietary protein moderation if very high intake
Screen for acromegaly if IGF-1 very elevated with symptoms

peer_reviewed_citations.citation: Milman S, Atzmon G, Huffman DM, et al. (2014) Low insulin-like growth factor-1 level predicts survival in humans with exceptional longevity. Aging Cell. 13(4):769-771
peer_reviewed_citations.relevance: Association of lower IGF-1 with longevity in centenarians

optimal_ranges_by_context.context: Longevity optimization in adults 40-60 years old
optimal_ranges_by_context.rationale: Below 150 ng/mL may indicate deficiency with sarcopenia risk; above 250 ng/mL may accelerate aging. Mid-range balances anabolism and longevity.

optimal_ranges_by_context.context: Longevity optimization in adults over 60 years old
optimal_ranges_by_context.rationale: Lower targets may be appropriate for older adults given cancer risk considerations. However, must balance against sarcopenia and frailty risk.

optimal_ranges_by_context.context: Athletic performance and recovery in competitive athletes
optimal_ranges_by_context.rationale: Higher IGF-1 supports muscle protein synthesis and recovery. May be appropriate for competitive athletes where performance is priority over longevity optimization.

interventions_affecting.notes: Primary physiologic stimulator of hepatic IGF-1 production
Stimulates endogenous GH release, less predictable than exogenous GH

interventions_affecting.magnitude: additive to GH effect (+50-100 ng/mL claimed)
interventions_affecting.notes: Anecdotal reports of enhanced IGF-1 response when combining carnitine with GH
Adequate protein required for IGF-1 synthesis; deficiency lowers IGF-1
Prolonged fasting suppresses IGF-1 as adaptive response

related_biomarkers.notes: IGF-1/IGFBP-3 ratio may better reflect bioavailable IGF-1
Insulin resistance affects hepatic IGF-1 response to GH

range_conflicts.topic: Optimal IGF-1 range for longevity in adults 40-60

position_a.detail: Balances anabolic function against longevity concerns

position_b.detail: More conservative target to minimize cancer/accelerated aging risk

range_conflicts.characterization: Different experts recommend different optimal ranges for the same population. The difference reflects different weighting of anabolic benefits versus longevity/cancer risk. Position A prioritizes maintaining muscle and function; Position B prioritizes longevity risk minimization.
range_conflicts.clinical_note: Both ranges are advocated by different practitioners. Consider individual patient factors: sarcopenia/frailty concerns favor higher range; cancer history or strong longevity focus favor lower range. Neither is definitively correct.
context_factors: Patient's cancer history or family history
Current IGF-1 level and direction of change
